origin_history: Seeds purchased and planted on Oct 8, 2025.
Reseeded on Nov 5, 2025 and topped with potting mix.
whats_been_logged: This arugula planting has progressed from reseeded recovery into a successful first baby-leaf harvest and is now rebuilding a dense regrowth canopy from intact crowns. Over time, soil moisture has been the main variable, with intentional dry-down and occasional saturation periods monitored to prevent root stress while supporting steady leaf rebound. Leaf posture, canopy thickness, and color have remained strong overall, keeping the planting on track for repeat cut-and-come harvests.
current_state: The arugula is actively regrowing after its first baby-leaf harvest, producing a dense, vigorous canopy of upright new leaves from intact crowns. Leaf color and posture are strong with no visible wilt, spotting spread, or pest damage. The root zone is currently very wet, so the planting is being allowed to dry down to maintain healthy oxygen levels and prevent saturation stress.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Repeat Harvests Every 3–7 Days (Maintain Baby Leaves)
Larger, More Serrated Leaves If Left Uncut

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high near 66°F and a low around 44°F. Wind chill values as low as 40 early.
journal.observations: Arugula is growing steadily with a dense canopy of mixed-size leaves. Several older lower leaves and cotyledons show yellowing and some purpling, while newer growth looks upright and healthy. Soil appears quite moist and the planter was indoors at the time of readings, so light exposure was low during measurement.
journal.actions: Do not water right now because moisture is already high. Bring the planter outside around 10:00 AM as planned once temperatures reach the mid-50s, and place it in full sun with good airflow. Remove any remaining dead or yellowed leaves that detach easily to keep airflow open.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture and wait to water until the planter dries down closer to mid-range moisture levels. Watch the newest leaves over the next couple of days; if they stay pale once watering is under control, consider a light feeding later, but prioritize drying rhythm and airflow first.

photos.caption: Top-down view of the arugula planter showing dense growth with a mix of mature and younger leaves and some thinning gaps in the center.
photos.tags: arugula, planter, top-down, dense growth, leaf color variation

photos.caption: Angled view of the canopy showing upright newer leaves and older lower leaves with some yellowing and purpling.
photos.tags: arugula, leaf health, older leaves, yellowing, canopy

photos.caption: Side view of the planter indoors showing overall plant density and uneven height from mixed maturity across the bed.
photos.tags: arugula, indoor, planter, growth stage, uneven canopy

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 59°F overnight. Tonight: Increasing Clouds. Tomorrow: Decreasing Clouds with a high of 69°F.
journal.observations: The arugula is actively regrowing after the recent thinning and cleanup, with a more open canopy and clearer spacing between clusters. Leaves are upright and generally healthy-looking, with a mix of smaller new growth and some larger leaves. Overall density is uneven but improving, and the soil surface appears moderately moist rather than dry.
journal.actions: Skip watering right now. Let the planter dry down a bit more, especially with the cooler day coming. If the surface looks dry later today, you can mist or lightly water only the driest sections rather than soaking the whole planter.
journal.next_steps: Tomorrow, reassess moisture by feel and/or a quick probe check before watering. Aim to water only when the top 1 inch is drying and the planter feels lighter. Keep watching for uneven dry-down across the tray and adjust watering to target the driest zones first.
journal.q_and_a_summary: With moisture still moderate-to-high in both sections (60–70%) and a cooler day ahead, watering now would keep the root zone too wet and slow recovery. The best move is to hold water this morning and resume only once the planter clearly dries down.
follow_up: [3:30 PM] 12/30/2025 - This window box was not watered but was covered given the temperature was forecased to drop down to 42°F overnight.
[9:00 AM] 12/31/2025 - This window box was uncovered and left outside to get sun
[6:00 PM] 12/31/2025 - This window box was brought inside given the temperature was forecased to drop down to 40°F overnight.

photos.caption: Close-up of the arugula canopy showing improved spacing and upright regrowth after thinning and cleanup.
Top-down view showing uneven density across the planter with open lanes and clusters of new growth.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula shows vigorous, upright baby-leaf growth with strong leaf posture and increasing leaf size suitable for continued light harvests. Canopy density remains high with no visible wilt, disease, or pest damage. A second probe reading taken nearby showed a 1% moisture value with very low EC/salt, which is consistent with probe contact failure rather than true tray dryness; the tray appears evenly moist and stable overall.
journal.actions: Do not water today or tomorrow morning because moisture is still elevated for a window box planting. If desired, perform a light harvest by cutting only the tallest leaves while leaving crowns intact to improve airflow and encourage a healthy dry-down cycle.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow afternoon and resume watering only if moisture drops to 35.00 or lower. Continue monitoring for steady dry-down in sunny weather and avoid scheduled watering while readings remain near 60 to prevent saturation stress.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water tomorrow morning and confirmed watering should be skipped because moisture remains elevated; also reviewed that the second probe reading showing 1% moisture is consistent with probe contact failure rather than true dryness.
follow_up: [9:00 AM] Fluffed the soil across the tray to improve airflow and even drying, pinched off old dead leaves, and trimmed the largest leaves to even out canopy height and encourage more uniform regrowth.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing dense, vigorous arugula regrowth with upright leaves and strong canopy structure under full sun.
Overhead follow-up view after soil fluffing and cleanup, showing improved airflow zones and a more even baby-leaf canopy after trimming larger leaves.
photos.tags: arugula, follow-up, canopy-evening, pruning, dead-leaf-removal, soil-fluffing

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula shows vigorous, upright baby-leaf growth with strong leaf posture and increasing leaf size suitable for continued light harvests. Canopy density remains high with no visible wilt, disease, or pest damage. A second probe reading taken nearby showed a 1% moisture value with very low EC/salt, which is consistent with probe contact failure rather than true tray dryness; the tray appears evenly moist and stable overall.
journal.actions: Do not water today or tomorrow morning because moisture is still elevated for a window box planting. If desired, perform a light harvest by cutting only the tallest leaves while leaving crowns intact to improve airflow and encourage a healthy dry-down cycle.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow afternoon and resume watering only if moisture drops to 35.00 or lower. Continue monitoring for steady dry-down in sunny weather and avoid scheduled watering while readings remain near 60 to prevent saturation stress.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water tomorrow morning and confirmed watering should be skipped because moisture remains elevated; also reviewed that the second probe reading showing 1% moisture is consistent with probe contact failure rather than true dryness.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing dense, vigorous arugula regrowth with upright leaves and strong canopy structure under full sun.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula shows strong, upright regrowth with thicker canopy density and increasing leaf size suitable for continued baby-leaf harvests. Leaf posture is firm with no visible wilt, pest damage, or spreading spotting. Soil moisture is slightly elevated and the surface appears evenly moist, indicating the root zone should be allowed to dry down before the next irrigation.
journal.actions: Do not water today because moisture is slightly high for a window box planting. If desired, perform a light harvest by cutting only the tallest leaves while leaving crowns intact to maintain regrowth and improve airflow.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow around the same time and resume watering only if moisture drops to 35.00 or lower. Continue maintaining full sun exposure and monitor leaf posture and color after any harvest to ensure steady regrowth without saturation stress.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing vigorous cut-and-come regrowth with thicker canopy density and larger baby leaves rising above the tray.
Angled view highlighting upright leaf posture and increased leaf size, with a moist but stable root zone supporting strong growth.
photos.tags: arugula, regrowth, leaf-size, upright, canopy, angled

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula shows dense, vigorous regrowth with upright leaves and thickening canopy structure suitable for continued baby-leaf harvests. Leaf posture is strong with no visible wilt, spotting progression, or pest damage. Soil moisture is stable in the mid-range and the surface appears evenly moist without saturation.
journal.actions: Skip watering tomorrow morning because soil moisture is already ideal. Continue normal sun exposure and maintain airflow. If desired, harvest lightly by cutting only the tallest leaves while leaving crowns intact.
journal.next_steps: Take the next probe readings tomorrow between 12–1 PM and water only if moisture drops to 35.00 or lower. Continue moisture-driven watering rather than daily watering to avoid returning the root zone to saturation. Monitor leaf color and posture after any harvest for steady regrowth.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to water tomorrow morning despite not being able to take readings until early afternoon; confirmed to skip morning watering and base watering on the 12–1 PM readings, watering only if moisture falls to 35.00 or lower.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing dense regrowth and an even baby-leaf canopy rebuilding strongly across the arugula section of the window box.
Angled close-up showing upright leaf posture and larger leaves emerging above the canopy, indicating strong post-harvest recovery.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula shows strong, dense regrowth with upright leaf posture and a thickening baby-leaf canopy. Leaves appear healthy and turgid with no visible wilt or active spotting. The soil remains heavily saturated, consistent with the high moisture reading and dark, moisture-retentive surface.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today due to very high soil moisture. Confirm planter drainage is clear and avoid disturbing crowns while the root zone dries. Optionally loosen only the top 1/4 inch of soil in a small area to improve surface evaporation.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow mid-morning and continue holding water until readings fall into the low-to-mid 30s. Retest pH once soil moisture returns to the mid-range to confirm whether alkalinity persists. Monitor for any yellowing or softness at the base that could indicate prolonged saturation.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing dense, healthy regrowth forming a thick baby-leaf canopy across the arugula section of the window box.
Angled side view highlighting upright leaf posture and vigorous new growth emerging above the canopy under bright sun.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight. A 10% chance of showers tonight, then patchy fog. Tomorrow mostly sunny with a high of 82°F.
journal.observations: Six days after the first harvest, the arugula shows strong, even regrowth from intact crowns with upright leaf posture and improving green coloration. Canopy density is rebuilding without crowding, and no signs of wilt, disease, rot, or pest activity are present. Soil moisture remains comfortably within the optimal range.
journal.actions: No watering performed due to adequate soil moisture and favorable weather conditions.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning. Resume watering only if readings fall into the low-to-mid 30s. Continue monitoring regrowth height and color in anticipation of the next light harvest.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing even regrowth and improving leaf color six days after harvest.
Angled view highlighting upright leaves and healthy regrowth structure under full sun conditions.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84°F dropping to around 61°F overnight. Partly cloudy tonight. Sunny tomorrow with a high near 82°F.
journal.observations: Five days after the first harvest, the arugula shows uniform regrowth from intact crowns with increasing canopy density and upright leaf posture. Leaf color is gradually deepening compared to earlier in the week. No signs of wilt, disease, rot, or pest activity were observed. Soil moisture remains adequate following earlier rainfall.
journal.actions: No watering performed due to sufficient soil moisture at the time of reading and favorable overnight conditions.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after 7:00 AM tomorrow. Water only if readings fall into the low-to-mid 30s. Continue monitoring regrowth height and color in anticipation of the next light harvest.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing even regrowth and rebuilding canopy density five days after harvest.
Angled view highlighting upright new leaves and healthy regrowth structure under warm late-day conditions.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight. A 20% chance of precipitation today.
journal.observations: Three days after the first harvest, the arugula shows clear regrowth from intact crowns with increasing leaf density and slightly deeper green coloration compared to earlier in the week. Canopy spacing remains open with good airflow. Leaves appear healthy with no signs of rot, pest damage, or stress. Soil is heavily saturated following several hours of intermittent rain this morning.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizing today due to saturated soil from rainfall. Ensured planter drainage remained unobstructed.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil moisture as it dries over the next 24–48 hours and resume watering only once readings fall below the optimal range. Continue observing color deepening and leaf thickening. Anticipate next light harvest once regrowth reaches 2–3 inches.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing active regrowth three days after harvest with improved spacing and early canopy refill.
Angled side view highlighting upright new leaves emerging from intact crowns following recent rainfall.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: One day after the first harvest, the arugula shows an open canopy with intact crowns and upright, healthy regrowth points. Leaf color remains lighter green, which is typical immediately after cutting, with no signs of wilting, rot, or pest damage. Overall structure indicates strong root support and good recovery.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow the plant to remain undisturbed to support clean regrowth.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture tomorrow morning after overnight rain chances. Expect visible new leaf growth within 48–72 hours and darker green color by day three or four post-harvest.

photos.caption: Overhead view one day after harvest showing evenly opened canopy with visible crowns and early regrowth points.
Angled view highlighting intact stems, upright leaf posture, and balanced spacing following the first cut.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula forms a dense baby-leaf canopy with strong upright growth and no signs of wilt, disease, or pest damage. Leaf color is lighter green overall, especially in the most crowded zones, while taller leaves along the edges show slightly deeper color. The appearance reflects active baby-leaf growth under cool soil conditions rather than nutrient deficiency.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. A light baby-leaf harvest may be performed by selectively cutting the tallest leaves above the crown.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture tomorrow morning, especially after wind exposure. Expect darker green regrowth within several days following the first light harvest. Continue avoiding fertilizer until after regrowth begins.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed why the arugula appears paler than grocery-store greens and confirmed this is normal for dense baby-leaf plantings prior to first harvest. Explained that cutting, not fertilizing, will naturally deepen leaf color.
follow_up: [7:45 AM] Performed first baby-leaf harvest, evenly trimming across the planter while leaving crowns intact. Canopy was opened up significantly, improving spacing and airflow for regrowth.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula before harvest showing a dense baby-leaf canopy with lighter green coloration typical of pre-harvest growth.
Angled side view prior to harvest highlighting taller edge leaves with slightly deeper green color than the crowded interior.
Post-harvest overhead view showing an evenly thinned canopy with intact crowns and improved spacing across the planter.
Closer view after harvest showing clean cut stems above the crown and healthy remaining leaves positioned for rapid regrowth.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight. Tonight: Partly cloudy with a slight chance of thunderstorms. Tomorrow: Partly sunny with a high of 71°F.
journal.observations: The arugula appears healthy and vigorous with dense, green baby-leaves forming. The right-hand side is showing more elongation and slightly darker green coloration, suggesting it’s nearing the ideal harvest window. No new pest or disease signs are visible, but some areas remain pale from earlier crowding.
journal.actions: No watering needed today; moisture is at a perfect level. Plan to harvest light baby-leaves in the next 1–2 days. Avoid additional fertilization for now as fertility is currently high.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture after tonight’s rain and recheck the soil tomorrow morning. Continue tracking regrowth and color improvement across the tray. Plan for the first light harvest within the next 1–2 days.

photos.caption: Overhead view of dense baby-leaf canopy.
Right-hand section of tray showing elongated, greener leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula tray is stable and vigorous with clear progression into harvestable baby-leaf size, especially on the right-hand side where leaves are longer and deeper green. Central and left sections remain dense with lighter cotyledons typical of crowding rather than stress. No new spotting, wilting, or pest damage is visible, and soil moisture appears evenly distributed.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as moisture is in an ideal dry-down range. Do not fertilize at this stage. Maintain current sun exposure and airflow. Optional preparation for first light baby-leaf harvest may begin within the next 24–48 hours.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture over the next 1–2 days and plan the next watering once readings fall into the mid-20s. After the first light harvest, expect improved airflow and more even leaf coloration across the tray. Recheck probe readings after harvest to guide regrowth care.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the full window box showing dense baby-leaf arugula with a stronger, larger-leaf cluster on the right and tighter, paler growth through the center and left.
Angled close-up of the right-hand section displaying elongated baby leaves with healthy green color and thicker blades, indicating readiness for a first light harvest.
Left-side section of the planter showing tightly packed younger seedlings with mild sun-related coloration and compact growth consistent with crowding.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73°F dropping to 53°F overnight.
journal.observations: The tray remains on the wet side with moisture at 80, though the seedlings do not appear waterlogged. The canopy continues to recover, with the right-hand section showing strong upright leaves and the center and left areas gradually greening. No new leaf spotting is present, and all older blemishes remain static. Cooler evening temperatures pose no risk and should help tighten leaf growth and deepen color.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as the tray needs additional dry-down. Hold fertilizing until moisture stabilizes in the mid-range. If desired, lightly lift the very top layer of soil in the densest patch to improve airflow, avoiding any root disturbance.
journal.next_steps: Expect moisture to fall into the 50–60 range by tomorrow afternoon with sunny, breezy conditions. Continue monitoring for color improvement and upward growth. Plan for micro-thinning once moisture normalizes. First baby-leaf harvest remains approximately 2–4 days away.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the forecasted overnight low of 53°F posed a risk and confirmed that arugula thrives in cool temperatures, with no protection needed. Reviewed that the plant continues to recover from prior dryness and oversaturation phases.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing gradual greening and improved turgor across the canopy.
Close-up of the right-hand section displaying upright, healthy leaves and no new spotting.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: The tray shows clear improvement with seedlings appearing more lifted, hydrated, and less stressed compared with yesterday. Color is shifting from pale yellow to a healthier light green, especially along the right side which shows strong leaf expansion. No new spotting or lesions are present, and existing marks remain dry and unchanged. The soil surface appears evenly moist rather than saturated, and the canopy overall shows signs of active recovery and renewed growth.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as moisture is in the ideal mid-range for arugula. Hold off on fertilizing and thinning for now while the tray continues stabilizing. Optionally rotate the planter 180 degrees to balance light exposure across the canopy.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow to ensure continued mid-range stability. Monitor for continued greening and upward growth, which should accelerate with today's ideal temperatures. Plan for a possible micro-thinning once the canopy evens out. Expect the first baby-leaf harvest window in 3–5 days if growth continues at this pace.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the arugula should be transplanted into a larger container and confirmed that moving to a new container is not recommended for baby-leaf production, as the current planter is ideal and transplanting would cause growth setbacks. Also reviewed which scissors are best for harvesting, confirming that lightweight garden scissors are better suited than heavy pruning shears for clean cuts and healthy regrowth.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing healthier leaf color and renewed upward growth across the tray.
Close-up of improved seedling turgor with no new spotting or lesions.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The tray remains fully saturated from yesterday's corrective watering and the top layer now includes new Moisture Control mix, resulting in a dark, evenly textured surface. Seedlings show slightly improved firmness and color compared with the previous day, with no expansion of leaf spots and no signs of water-soaked or infectious lesions. Pale yellow-green foliage persists in the more crowded zones, while the taller right-hand cluster continues to look greener and stronger. No new damage is present, and the uneven canopy reflects recent dry stress rather than placement issues.
journal.actions: Do not water today, as the root zone is fully saturated. Avoid fertilizing until moisture decreases into the mid-range. Leave the planter in place and allow the tray to air out naturally. Remove only heavily blemished leaves if desired, and avoid thinning until seedlings fully stabilize.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow to confirm the tray is drying from the 90 range toward normal levels. Monitor for new lesions on fresh growth, as existing spotting reflects older stress. Consider temporary rain protection later today if showers are heavy, since the soil is already saturated. Expect gradual color improvement as moisture normalizes.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the arugula should be transplanted into a larger or different container and confirmed that transplanting is not recommended for dense baby-leaf arugula, as it causes shock and delays harvest. Confirmed that the current planter is ideal for producing supermarket-style baby arugula. Also discussed choosing appropriate cutting scissors for harvesting and recommended lightweight garden scissors over heavy pruning shears for clean, even cuts and better regrowth.
follow_up: [Morning] Filled the probe hole, fluffed the soil, and added Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix to improve contact and leveling.

photos.caption: Close-up showing greener upper leaves in the taller right-hand section and pale seedlings in the more crowded zones.
Overhead view showing saturated soil, static leaf spots, and slightly improved canopy turgor.
The right side of the tray displaying stronger leaf coloration and no new lesion development.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The tray shows better turgor and recovery compared to yesterday, with leaves standing more upright and no signs of wilt. Pale yellow-green coloration is still present across much of the canopy, but bronzing and purple veining have not expanded. The small circular leaf spots remain scattered and static, with no coalescing or water-soaked margins. Growth remains uneven with a taller, greener band on the right. Soil is deeply rehydrated and dark, consistent with the high moisture reading, while pH and EC remain in healthy ranges.
journal.actions: Do not apply neem or copper today. Allow the soil to dry back naturally from the high moisture level and avoid fertilizing until moisture returns to mid-range levels. Remove only the worst affected leaves if desired. Maintain normal sun exposure.
journal.next_steps: Monitor over the next 24–48 hours for any new lesions on new leaves or for rapid expansion of existing spots. Recheck moisture tomorrow and expect greening as moisture stabilizes. If disease characteristics emerge later, plan a copper treatment on a dry morning with no rain forecast for 24 hours.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether to apply neem or copper fungicide for the leaf spots and confirmed that the current spotting pattern aligns with dryness-related stress and minor abrasion rather than active fungal disease. Recommended withholding treatment for now and monitoring for progression.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing uneven growth, pale coloration, and static leaf spotting after rehydration.
Mid-level view showing taller, greener growth on the right side contrasting with shorter pale seedlings.
Close-up of the central area showing scattered static spots and pale leaves without signs of fungal spread.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 86°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: The soil surface is extremely dry, matching the difficulty you had inserting the probe and explaining the invalid pH reading. Moisture at depth is moderate, but the top layer is dusty and hydrophobic. Seedlings appear pale yellow-green across most of the tray, with some bronzing and purple veining where dryness has restricted nutrient uptake. Growth is uneven, with a taller, greener band on the right and shorter, paler seedlings elsewhere. Scattered leaf speckles are present but do not form a disease pattern.
journal.actions: Apply a moderate watering to rehydrate the upper 1–1.5 inches of soil. Avoid fertilizing today because roots cannot absorb nutrients evenly when the surface is this dry. Keep the planter in normal sun and water in the morning going forward to prevent midday dry-out.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later this afternoon or tomorrow morning to track absorption. Only water again when moisture drops into the low 20s and the surface becomes pale and dusty. Monitor leaf color over the next 48–72 hours for improvement as moisture stabilizes.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing pale seedlings, uneven growth, and a dry soil surface.
Close-up view of seedlings with pale color, bronzing, and scattered leaf speckles.
Dense seedling area displaying yellow-green foliage and mild purple veining.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula tray shows a dense canopy of seedlings with many true leaves, and the right-hand cluster is noticeably taller than the rest. Earlier in the afternoon the soil became bone dry in the sun and the probe could not get a reading, but after watering the surface now looks dark and fully rehydrated, consistent with the high moisture value. Some older leaves show scattered tan and gray spots and minor edge damage while newer growth remains cleaner and more uniform.
journal.actions: Do not water again today; moisture is already high and the root zone needs time to dry back toward the mid-range. Avoid fertilizing or using copper or neem products at this stage, and instead gently remove the worst spotted leaves with clean scissors if they bother you. Keep the tray in its usual sun exposure while avoiding overhead wetting of foliage late in the day.
journal.next_steps: Monitor the spotted leaves over the next several days and watch for any rapid increase in the number or size of lesions. Recheck moisture once the top inch of soil feels dry and only water again when probe readings fall into the 20–35 mS/cm range. If spotting begins to spread or lesions become dark and water-soaked, plan a light treatment with copper or neem on a calm, dry morning while continuing to protect new growth.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the small tan and gray spots and tiny holes on older leaves represented a serious leaf-spot problem. Explained that the pattern looks like mild early spotting and physical wear on crowded baby leaves rather than an aggressive disease, and recommended focusing on monitoring, removing the worst leaves, and reserving copper or neem treatments for clear progression.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula tray showing dense seedlings, a taller cluster of true leaves on the right side, and moist, freshly watered soil.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The seedlings form a continuous baby-leaf carpet with a distinct stand of taller plants on the right. Leaf color is mostly light to medium green with some purpling along stems and veins in the more crowded zones. Soil appears evenly moist but not saturated, matching the mid-range moisture reading, and there are no new major lesions or wilt despite strong midday sun.
journal.actions: Allow the tray to continue drying slightly and avoid watering immediately, as the moisture level is still serviceable for established seedlings in full sun. Hold off on any fertilizer adjustments while pH is near neutral and plants are maintaining steady growth. Keep the planter in its current light exposure and avoid disturbing roots while the canopy is this dense.
journal.next_steps: Check the soil by feel either later this evening or tomorrow morning and plan a light watering only once the top inch feels dry and moisture readings fall noticeably below the mid-20s. Continue to watch the more purple and pale leaves for any worsening pattern that might indicate nutrient stress, and plan a gentle feeding with your 4-5-5 product later in the week if color continues to wash out.

photos.caption: Overhead photo of the arugula tray at midday showing a dense baby-leaf canopy and a taller patch of plants on the right side.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight, with wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: The tray is very full, with seedlings overlapping into a thick mat and larger true leaves becoming more prominent, especially on the right side. Leaf color is still on the pale side but generally uniform, with some purplish tones along stems and undersides in crowded areas. Soil looks dark and evenly moist, consistent with the high moisture reading and the recent pattern of regular watering.
journal.actions: Skip watering today; the root zone is already well hydrated and additional water would risk keeping the mix too wet under warm, breezy conditions. Hold off on any granular fertilizer applications until moisture drops closer to the mid-range, as nutrients are already adequate for baby-leaf growth. Maintain current light levels and continue protecting the tray from the strongest gusts so the shallow roots are not disturbed.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture in about 24 hours or sooner if the surface lightens significantly in color. Once readings fall into the 30–40 mS/cm range and the top inch feels dry, plan a moderate watering and consider a very light application of your 4-5-5 fertilizer along the outer edges of the tray. Continue to monitor leaf color and thickness as the stand moves fully into harvestable baby-leaf stage.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula tray with a dense, overlapping canopy of baby leaves and moist dark soil.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy through the day with temperatures in the mid-70s°F, possible showers around 6:00 PM, and a low near 69°F overnight.
journal.observations: By late afternoon the arugula stand presents a solid baby-leaf mat, with a cluster of taller, paddle-shaped leaves on the right and smaller, rounder leaves filling the rest of the tray. Many leaves are still a soft yellow-green with some purpling on stems and undersides, reflecting earlier stress and crowding, but overall turgor is good and there is no active wilt. Soil appears evenly moist and slightly dark, matching the mid-to-high moisture reading and the mostly cloudy, humid conditions.
journal.actions: Do not water again this evening; moisture is already comfortably high and showers are possible around sunset. Avoid fertilizing or applying any foliar products so close to potential rain and overnight humidity. Leave the tray in place to enjoy the mild temperatures and allow the root zone to stabilize at this current moisture level.
journal.next_steps: Check the tray again the following day during mid-morning sun to see how quickly the soil is drying and whether leaf color is holding steady. Plan to water only when probe readings slip toward the 30s and the top inch of mix feels dry. Continue to watch the contrast between the taller right-hand cluster and the shorter center for any signs that shading is limiting light to the smallest seedlings.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula tray near evening, showing a dense baby-leaf canopy with taller leaves on the right and paler, crowded seedlings toward the center.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 66°F overnight, with partly cloudy conditions around 1:00 PM and wind gusts up to 15 mph.
journal.observations: The stand has thickened further, with many overlapping baby leaves and a clearly taller, lusher section on the right side of the tray. Leaf color is still fairly light overall with hints of purple along stems and undersides in some plants, but the canopy looks vigorous and upright. The soil had been watered at 9:40 AM and now appears evenly moist but not waterlogged, aligning with the mid-50s moisture reading under bright but variable sun.
journal.actions: Do not add more water today; the morning watering has brought the root zone into a comfortable range and the tray will continue to dry through the breezy afternoon. Avoid fertilizing again while salts are moderately elevated and plants are still recovering from earlier swings in moisture. Maintain full sun exposure so the dense canopy continues to thicken and the smaller seedlings can catch up.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow late morning before the sun is at its peak and plan the next watering only when readings drift back toward the 30s and the surface lightens noticeably. Continue watching for any sections that consistently lag behind in growth or color, as these may benefit from slightly thinner spacing during your first harvest.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula tray in early afternoon showing a dense canopy with a particularly vigorous patch of taller leaves on the right and evenly moist soil.

journal.conditions: Weather conditions for this day were not captured in the conversation; please fill this in from your original notes.
journal.observations: The arugula seedlings now form a nearly continuous mat with many cotyledons and a growing number of small true leaves. Leaf color is light green with noticeable red or purple coloration along veins and stems in several plants, especially in the densest patches. Soil looks moist but not saturated, consistent with a mid-30s moisture reading in cool conditions.
journal.actions: Hold off on watering for now; the moisture level is adequate and the plants are not showing signs of wilt. Do not adjust pH or apply fertilizer today, as readings and growth are both within a comfortable range for crowded baby arugula. Maintain the current light exposure while avoiding unnecessary disturbance of the root zone.
journal.next_steps: Monitor the red and purple veining over the next few days to confirm it remains a cosmetic color shift rather than a spreading deficiency pattern. Plan to water once the top inch of soil feels dry and probe readings fall closer to the mid-20s. Continue to track how quickly the soil dries on cool, bright mornings versus warmer afternoons.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether the red and purple veins and undersides on some leaves were a cause for concern. Clarified that this type of color shift is common in dense, sun-exposed arugula seedlings and can reflect normal pigmentation and mild environmental stress rather than a severe nutrient problem, with a recommendation to monitor rather than treat immediately.

photos.caption: Close-up of arugula seedlings showing dense growth with light green leaves and noticeable red and purple veining on some foliage.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 65°F overnight, with rainy conditions expected around 6:00 PM.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain dense and upright with a mix of round cotyledons and emerging true leaves, and a slightly taller patch is becoming more prominent on the right. Leaf color is a soft green with a few paler and slightly discolored leaves scattered through the canopy, but there is no broad yellowing or wilt. The soil surface looks moderately moist, and you have begun refilling and leveling the probe holes with extra mix to prevent pockets from forming.
journal.actions: Skip additional watering for now; moisture is adequate and rain is expected later in the day, which will further hydrate the tray. Avoid fertilizing while conditions are cool and cloudy and the fertility reading is already comfortable for young arugula. Continue gently backfilling probe holes with fresh soil as you have been doing to keep the surface level and prevent roots from drying out in air gaps.
journal.next_steps: After the expected evening rain, check the tray the following day to ensure the soil has not become waterlogged, and only water again once readings slide back toward the low 30s. Continue watching for any expansion of the paler leaves in the center and plan to thin lightly once the first baby-leaf harvest window opens so light reaches seedlings that are currently shaded.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the arugula tray on a cloudy afternoon showing dense seedlings, a slightly taller patch on the right, and a leveled soil surface where probe holes have been filled.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The arugula tray shows a very dense carpet of young seedlings with bright green cotyledons and early true leaves beginning to rise above the canopy. Earlier in the morning the soil was extremely dry and crumbly, but a light watering about 45 minutes before the reading has darkened the mix and brought moisture into a moderate range. Plants look perky with no wilt or obvious nutrient problems, though the quick dry-down pattern of the sandier mix is still evident.
journal.actions: Do not water again immediately since the light watering has already rehydrated the upper root zone and the moisture reading is now moderate. Hold off on any fertilizer or pH correction for the moment, as pH and fertility are acceptable for seedlings and there is no visible stress. Keep the tray in full sun and continue to insert the probe carefully to avoid creating deep pockets in the soft mix.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture again either later this afternoon or tomorrow morning to see how fast the tray is drying under partly cloudy skies, and plan a more thorough watering only if readings fall back toward the low 20s or the surface becomes crumbly again. Continue watching for any areas that fall behind in growth so they can be helped by light thinning once the first baby leaves size up.

photos.caption: Overhead photo of the arugula tray around midday showing a dense stand of seedlings and soil that has recently been rehydrated after earlier dryness.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain vigorous, upright, and bright green with early true leaves expanding across the tray. Canopy density continues to improve and the previously stressed thinning area remains small and stable. Soil surface is extremely dry again, consistent with repeated readings of zero moisture and the fast-drying behavior of the sand-amended mix. Despite the dryness, seedlings show no wilt or stress.
journal.actions: A light to moderate watering is recommended to rehydrate the upper root zone without oversaturating the tray. No fertilizer or pH correction required due to ideal pH and low EC.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture again later today to ensure the watering absorbs evenly. Continue tracking moisture swings and watch for signs of heat-related dryness on sunny afternoons.
follow_up: [1:54 PM] Applied light shower to rehydrate the tray.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense seedlings, bright green color, and visibly dry soil surface under full sun.
photos.tags: arugula, seedlings, tray, dry-soil, growth, sun

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain dense, bright, and upright with early true leaves continuing to develop. The canopy is noticeably fuller than the day before. The soil surface is extremely dry, matching the zero moisture reading and the difficulty inserting the probe. Despite the dryness, seedlings have not yet wilted, but the upper root zone is at risk of stress if not rehydrated. No yellowing, pests, or signs of nutrient deficiency are present.
journal.actions: A moderate watering is recommended to rehydrate the top 1–1.5 inches of soil without oversaturating the tray. No fertilizer or pH adjustment applied, as readings are ideal for seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later today to ensure the watering hydrated the upper root zone evenly. Continue monitoring pH for stability and maintain full sun exposure while watching for heat-related drying.
follow_up: [11:19 AM] Applied moderate watering according to recommendations.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense seedlings under partial sun and visibly dry soil surface.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain dense, bright green, and vigorous with upright posture. Early true-leaf development is beginning and the canopy is filling evenly. No visible stress, wilting, or yellowing is present. The previously thin or stressed patch is now nearly indistinguishable as growth has thickened. Moisture level is moderate, and pH is slightly alkaline but not causing visible issues.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer applied because moisture is adequate and fertility is appropriate for seedlings. No pH correction applied while soil remains evenly moist.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture in the morning to track overnight drying. Continue full-sun exposure while monitoring for heat stress on warmer days. If pH remains in the mid–high 7s after the next irrigation cycle, consider a light acidifying watering.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense, healthy seedlings under full sun and early true-leaf formation.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain dense, bright green, and upright with the canopy approaching a full baby-leaf cover. Early true leaves are visible. Soil appears dry and loose, matching the probe reading indicating no measurable moisture. No yellowing, burn, or pest signs observed. The older thinning-stress patch is still present but stable.
journal.actions: Applied a controlled watering to rehydrate the full root zone, using two passes to ensure proper absorption. No fertilizer or pH correction applied due to current dryness levels and seedling growth stage.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later in the afternoon and again tomorrow morning. Consider mild shade during peak heat if leaves show stress. Plan a pH recheck when soil is evenly moist.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense seedlings and dry soil surface under bright midday sun.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82–85°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings are very dense and bright green with upright posture, and early true leaves are beginning to appear across the tray. Soil surface is visibly wet, matching the very high moisture reading, with no signs of wilting, yellowing, or pest damage. The small thinning-stress patch near the label remains stable and does not affect overall vigor.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer applied today because moisture is extremely high and plants look healthy. Tray is kept in full sun while avoiding further disturbance in the most crowded zones.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture later and only water again if levels drop into the 3–4 range. Continue normal sun exposure and provide cold protection if nighttime temperatures approach 45°F.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether inserting a probe into the crowded seedlings would rip them. Explanation that a few seedlings might be disturbed but the overall tray would be fine, with recommendations to probe at edges, gaps, or shallow angles to minimize root disturbance.

photos.caption: Arugula tray showing dense, vigorous seedlings.
Probe being inserted into the Arugula tray, demonstrating tight spacing between seedlings.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings are vigorous and evenly distributed with bright green cotyledons and upright growth. Canopy density has increased since earlier readings and the previous thinning-stress patch is less noticeable relative to the rest of the tray. Soil surface appears moist, consistent with the high moisture reading, and there are no signs of stress or pest issues.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer applied because moisture is still high and plants appear healthy. Tray is kept in full sun under mild temperatures.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture later in the day and water only if levels drop toward the 3–4 range. Retest pH within the next day to confirm stability and continue cold protection if temperatures drop near 45°F.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense, healthy seedlings.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The tray is densely filled with bright green seedlings that look upright and evenly distributed. A small pale patch near the label reflects earlier thinning stress but is stable and not spreading. Soil is fully moist from recent watering, and plant appearance does not show any symptoms of extremely high pH despite the probe reading.
journal.actions: No additional watering or fertilizer applied because soil is already saturated and plants appear healthy. No pH correction performed, as the reading is likely skewed by wet conditions or probe residue.
journal.next_steps: Allow the soil surface to dry slightly before the next watering and retest pH under less saturated conditions. Maintain full sun exposure and continue to protect from cold nights if temperatures approach 45°F.

photos.caption: Arugula tray showing dense seedling growth.

journal.conditions: 67°F, in shade but expected to be sunny within about 20 minutes.
journal.observations: Seedlings are thickening nicely across the tray with bright, healthy green coloration and upright posture. The pale cluster near the label matches the earlier thinning-stress area but is not worsening. Soil appears evenly moist and well-aerated, with no signs of dryness, wilting, or pests.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizer applied because analog readings and soil appearance indicate ideal conditions. Tray is left to move into full sun once the shade period ends.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later in the day and water only if it drops toward the dry range. Maintain full sun exposure and continue providing cold protection when night temperatures are forecast near 45°F.

photos.caption: Arugula tray with dense, evenly green seedlings.

journal.conditions: 65°F, full sun.
journal.observations: Tray is filled with young seedlings showing generally good color but growing in soil that is very dry at the surface. Analog readings indicate low fertility, dryness, and an alkaline pH, though plants are still standing upright. New growth from reseeding is visible and filling in previously thin areas.
journal.actions: Applied deep soaking after readings, and added additional water when the surface still appeared very dry. No fertilizer or pH correction applied yet, pending response to improved moisture.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture later the same day to ensure water has penetrated through the root zone and that the surface is no longer bone dry. Monitor pH in future readings and plan a light acidifying watering if alkaline readings persist once moisture is stable.

photos.caption: Arugula tray after deep watering, with many young seedlings.

journal.conditions: Full sun in mid-afternoon; temperature not recorded, brought indoors the previous night for cold protection.

analog_probe.moisture: Top inch bone dry with slight moisture just below

journal.observations: Reseeded tray shows a lot of fresh, even new growth despite earlier thinning damage, with many small seedlings emerging across the surface. The top inch of soil is bone dry, with only a little moisture detectable slightly deeper. Plants do not yet show severe stress but are at risk of drying out if not re-watered.
journal.actions: Applied light watering to re-moisten the top layer of soil while preserving the new seedlings and avoiding over-saturation. Continued to protect the tray from cold by bringing it indoors overnight as needed.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture closely over the next day to ensure the top layer does not return to bone-dry conditions. Continue gentle watering as needed while seedlings establish and maintain cold protection on chilly nights.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that reseeding and potting mix were added on November 5, 2025.

photos.caption: Arugula tray showing fresh new seedlings after reseeding.
